channel.title: Just a general question
channel.description:
So my Computer teacher was teaching my class about VB, and she said the difference between Interpreters and Compilers was that an Interpreter read the lines of code one by one, while a Compiler just read the whole thing. Then she said that a compiler's advantage is that it's fast, but doesn't show any errors, while an interpreter shows errors.
Is this even correct? This is what was written in our books, so if it's right i'll just throw this book away.

item.title: Just a general question
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

Thanks and Thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Just a general question
item.dc:creator: @PeeHPee PeeHPee
item.description:
@PeeHPee wrote:

An interpreter reads the code and executes its instructions at run time while a compiler writes the instructions to a file at compile-time to be used at run-time.

Read full topic

item.title: Just a general question
item.dc:creator: @lurtz1230 lurtz1230
item.description:
@lurtz1230 wrote:

an interpreter doesnt fully run the line of code in pure machine language, while a compiler compiles the human recognizable code into machine language so the computer can understand. Compilers r faster since the code is less refined.

Read full topic
